Fuck! He presses a hand on his wound. Maddox's face is a mass of blood, hands to his eyes. But keeps stepping on the pedal, McKnight steering, neck blee

Still strapped to his seat Durant sees the Black Hawk fly overhead. Hears Somali voices, yelling, coming closer. Tries to rea back for his rifle, grunts in agony, back damaged. Can't to it. Sweating, reaching, swearing in pain as -- SOMALI FACES appear in his windscreen, raise their AKs at him. D raises one arm to protect himself as he fires -- the firs Somali gunmen's chest EXPLODES. Gordon and Shughart land. GUNFIRE raging as they charge t the chopper. DURANT - Somalis charge the Black Hawk. Durant fires away He sees Shughart and Gordon rounding the corner, boots slapping earth. Appearing like angels. They fire at the approaching Somalis. Shughart bangs on the Black Hawk.
Friendlies! Shughart checks Frank's pulse.
God, it's good to see!
Oh, it's good to see you. How bad?
My leg's broken. My back feels kinda weird. (CONTINUED)
We gotta get you outta here, buddy. I'm pulling him out. Cover! Gordon gently lifts Durant from the chopper and he scream in pain. Shughart covers.
I'm gonna put you down. They prop him against a wall.
Cross, we're at the Six Four crash sight, securing the perimeter. You all right?
Yeah, I'm good. Shughart puts Durant's MP-5 in his hands.
You're locked and loaded. If you see anyone come around these corners -- you watch your back. Shughart and Gordon run back to the crash site.
Hey! Where's the rescue squad?
We're it! Durant is left alone, cradling his MP-5.
Steele talks to Harrell on the radio.
C2, you keep talking about a convoy, I would dearly like to know where in sam hill that is, over?
Perimeter has to be tighter for the convoy. You're too far from the crash. They spread out like that, and you're all liable to be overrun. Over. (CONTINUED)
C2, if I use two men for each wounded, I still got nobody left to shoot. Now, we're staying where we are, over? Ruiz sighs.

In the lead Humvee of the Lost Convoy, Maddox mops at his bloodied face while McKnight, peering out the broken windshield, drives, his neck a mess of blood... McKnight finds himself in front of a familiar building -- the target building.
Stop, stop, stop, stop, stop, Maddox, stop! INT. MCKNIGHT'S HUMVEE - CONT. Maddox face is a bloody mess. He slams on the brakes.
(resigned, into radio) Son of a bitch! Romeo Six Four we're right back where we started! I'm running low on ammo. I got many wounded, including me. Vehicles that are barely running.
Okay, Danny, I need a no bcs. assessment here. Can you get to the crash site? McKnight hears groans of the wounded in back, sounds of t rims grinding on the road, bullets smacking into metal.
Colonel, I can't see shit.
Negative. With the amount of wounded we have, we'd do more harm than good. We need to come back to base, rearm and regroup and then we can go back out.
Monitoring this, Garrison speaks into a headset.
C2...bring 'em back. Get 'em out of there!
Roger, return to base. INT. MCKNIGHT'S HUMVEE - CONT. McKnight shouts to the wounded men in back.

We're going home. Let's go! Left! Go, go, go, go, god dammit! Run that mother fucker over! Go, go, go! Left, left, left, left, left! We're gonna be home in a second, we're gonna be home in a second. Hang on! God dammit, you guys hang on!
Galentine throws his radio headset down.
What's up?
They're sending 'em back. The convoy's headed back to base camp. Some of the other men hear it and look over to Eversmann. What now? What does he suggest now?
Oh, now that makes sense, don't it? We need to exfil the wounded now, and get the hell outta here before its too late!
If Colonel McKnight went back to base, then he had a damn good reason. It changes nothing. Right now, some of his men don't seem too convinced. (CONTINUED)

All right, listen up. We're gonna hold the perimeter. We're gonna hold the strongpoint. Hooah! Eversmann looks at each man, into the wide, scared eyes o Smith, Galentine, Kurth, Goodale, Waddell and Doc Schmid.
(in unison) Hooah!
Conserve your ammo. Only shoot at what you can hit. Hooah?
(in unison) Hooah! His men stare out into the city, gripping weapons. Fear turning to anger, confusion into focus.
The convoy's gonna come. We're gonna get home.

Delta snipers GORDON AND SHUGHART are sprawled out under ruined chopper tail, ammo magazines piled beside them. THEY FIRE at endless targets. Countless AK-47 muzzle flas flare from every direction. A living nightmare.
Loading. Gordon slaps in an ammo mag, Shughart covering them. GORDON'S POV - firing again, he hits EVERYTHING. Militia nailed in the head, chest, some targets 100 yeards away.
Randy, I need a pistol mag! Shughart throws Gordon the mag and he loads it.
Loading. (CONTINUED)
205 206 207 GORDON FIRES AT MILITIA. OVERHEAD - THOUSANDS OF SOMALIS edge closer to them -- an armed, furious mob that will stop at nothing. Shughart grabs a magazine.
Loading. Gordon grabs a magazine. Pile of ammo getting smaller. ON THE PILE OF MAGAZINES - Gordon reaches for the last on
Randy, last mag! Crowd of Somalis now charging at them, making suicide run Too many of them. Gordon takes a bullet in the head.
Gordy! Shughart runs in to Gordon.
Fuck!

Durant is firing his MP-5 at dozens of Somalis. Every tim he fires they disappear behind walls. Shughart scrambles back to Durant, gives him a CAR-15 rifle. The weapon is covered in blood. Gordon's. Shughart touches Durant's shoulder.
Good luck. Shughart again crawls under the chopper as -- SOMALIS pee around the corner. Durant fires at them. Two more gunmen poke their heads around. Durant fires again.
Hundreds of Somalis race towards the crash site.
Garrison speaks to Cribbs in the subdued JOC. (CONTINUED)

We need the 10th Mountain in there. Everything they got. Pakistanis, Malays, I want their tanks and APCs. On the monitors, Garrison can see roadblocks going up in streets surrounding Wolcott's crash, boxing the Americans in.
They still don't know we've gone in.

Look. We have stirred up the hornet's nest here. We're fighting the entire city. I want every vehicle possible. If it has four wheels and armor, get it! Get everything. Garrison and Cribbs consult a map of Mogadishu, hostile a safe areas outlined in red and green.

Easy, go easy. Easy. Go easy. A Ranger shines a light on Wolcott's buried legs. It's hopeless.
He stares at the screen. Garrison can see Somalis again massing around three streets, choking off the convoy's ex
Colonel, what is going on down there? INTERCUT to McKnight on radio --
They're dismantling the entire cockpit around the body.
Well how long's it gonna take? I need an honest, no shit assessment. There's a pause as McKnight relays the question. Then --
They can't say.

head_text.subj: GARRISON. HE ENDURES AS LONG AS HE CAN THE 27
FLARES ON THE SCREEN HE KNOWS ARE RPGS. EVENTUALLY, INTO

text: Danny, no one gets left behind. INTERCUT to McKnight --
You understand me, son? INTERCUT to McKnight. No response.
Danny? INTERCUT to Garrison. Finally -- (CONTINUED)
Yes, General.
You do what you have to do.
Roger.
Briley's body is carried away from the Black Hawk
5:45 A.M. - Monday, October 4 Gunfire rains down on the men.
Let's go! Let's move out! The convoy starts to roll out. Rangers follow on foot.
Hoot sets explosives in the now-deserted cockpit. Runs to the leaving convoy as the charges are detonated.
The convoy is picking up speed, the Mountain soldiers scrambling to get aboard Humvees and APCs as Eversmann, Sanderson, and the other Rangers and Delta cover them.

After the last of the APCs pass, Eversmann and the other Rangers and Delta try to get aboard. EVERY VEHICLE is cra full, some men hanging out open doors, some lying on hood No one stops for them. Steele runs alongside the APC, pou on the metal --
Open up the hatch! We got men back here!
No room here, go on the roof.
What's going on? (CONTINUED)
The roof?
I'm not getting on the fucking roof!
No, no, no, it's full! The Pakistani driver shouts. Steele shuts the door. There are no more vehicles to chas after.
Let's just go, let's just go! The convoy pulls out and the men follow on foot.

The city is bathed in orange light. Eversmann, Hoot, Stee Sanderson, Twombly, Sizemore, Nelson, Yurek, Kurth, Wadde Galentine and Doc Schmid are running down the streets aft the convoy, unable to catch up with the vehicles. They watch helplessly as the convoy disappears down the b Their tired, rubbery legs carry them away from the crash site, into the dense, dangerous streets of surrounding neighborhoods.

The group of soldiers are now running along the same stre they battled over the day before. The men are exhausted, gasping for air as they charge dow the crooked, dirty roads. Legs like lead weights. KRATAKRATAKRAT! Machine-gun fire rakes the road ahead. Th group runs for cover, trying not to get pinned in.
The Rescue Convoy rumbles, stretching back a quarter mile The sound of the vehicles shakes the very earth. An older Somali man carries a dead child and crosses in front of t convoy.
The group runs down the street. Gasping. They can see the convoy disappearing around a corner. (CONTINUED)

Sanderson and Hoot FIRE down the intersection, killing th Somali snipers. Steele, Eversmann and others charge acros On the other side, the Rangers cover Delta Hoot and Sande The Delta Operators charge across to safety. They use this tactic at every intersection. Somali gunfir getting more intense. The men see the APCs, distant block ahead, rounding a corner.

Sanderson charges up from behind, bullets following him. THEY RUN out into the street as -- A WOMAN with a child i her arms dashes out in front of them, hurrying across the street. Waddell almost fires on instinct.
Get down, get outta here! The woman runs to the other side of the street. Sanderson runs over to Eversmann.
I'm out of ammo! Sanderson, I'm out of ammo! Sanderson continues to fire. Another woman runs forward, Kurth raises his weapon to fi
What are you doing?
I'm doing it. The woman RAISES A HANDGUN -- Kurth fires and she falls d

The group runs down the street, bullets whizzing past. The men charge down the block on wobbly legs, running thr the smoke. People line the streets, cheering them on. They run into the safety of THE SOCCER STADIUM.  281 282 283 124.

The entrance is in sight. Doctors are inside, white table and sheets and water and safety and food and shelter and Eversmann makes it. Hoot, Sanderson, Steele, and the othe charge in after him. They stare at the makeshift medical tents that have been up. Watching a Medic directing the seriously wounded to o area, dead to another - as UN workers bring them glasses of water. Nelson and Twombly embrace. Eversmann staggers forward.
BEHIND THEM - Colonel McKnight gets his neck wound looked at.
Ah, shit.
The bullet missed your jugular by about three millimeters. Don't move!
All right, all right. Hurry up, hurry up! BEHIND HIM - Grimes, covered in white dust, rests on a li Sanderson walks over to him and hands him a cup.
Little short on coffee, but I got you some tea. How you doing soldier?
I can't feel a thing.

Garrison, standing by the door, has come into the chaos t is the medical tent, watching. Somebody shouts,"... mop.. And we see doctors and medics working over a man, the man bleeding profusely, the doctors and the medics literally slipping in his blood on the floor... And Garrison seeing mop nearby takes it up, and doing his duty, mops the bloo floor... And as Garrison mops the bloody floor the doctor and the medics are trying to save his men's lives...  284 285 125.
Steele moves through the tent... men in various condition none of it good... He comes to Ruiz. The medic shakes his head no.
Hey son, hey. Ruiz opens his eyes.
Captain.
Lorenzo? How're you doing?
I went in and out. Medic says I should be okay in a couple of days.
That's great news.
Are we going after them?
You bet your ass we will. We gotta regroup.
Don't go out there without me. Don't go back out there without me. I can still do my job. Steele puts his hand on Ruiz' face.
Now you get some rest now.
Eversmann comes over to Hoot, who is picking through supplies... resupplying himself. Hoot goes about his business... taping grenade pins one after another after another... Calmly, efficiently...
(incredibly) You're going back in? (CONTINUED)
(nods, matter of fact) There's still men out there... God damn! He stops resupplying and picks up a plate and eats.

When I go home... and people ask me, hey Hoot? Why do you do it man? Why? You some kind of war junkie? I won't say a god damned word. Why? Because they won't understand... They won't understand why we do it. They won't understand, it's about the men next to you... and that's it... that's all it is. Eversmann does know... and starts to resupply himself. Ho shakes his head no.

Hey. Don't even think about it, all right? I'm better on my own. And fully resupplied Hoot simply starts off... Eversmann watches Hoot walk away... And Hoot suddenly slows, realizing... shouting back...
(congratulations) Hey! We started a whole new week... it's Monday. And as he moves off... just another soldier, one of the d of war...
Kids play on the downed helicopter.

I was talking to Blackburn the other day, and he asked me, "You know what changed? Why are we going home?" And I said, "Nothing..." But that's not true, you know? I think everything's changed. I know I've changed...  287 127.

Fluorescent lights... too bright.. too constant... a cool humming... it kicks off and then on again...and we see EVERSMANN... And he's clean... just some nicks and cuts, band-aid pieces over some small wounds... but there are o wounds, the kind you can't see at first glance...a soldie who's been in combat... a look in a young man's eyes... a look that makes you stop and take a deeper look... into h soul... and that's just what we do... looking at his face into his eyes...into the window of his soul... as he's ta to someone... easy, conversational... nothing out of the ordinary...

You know, a friend of mine asked me before I got here, it was when we were all shipping out. He asked me... "why are you going to fight somebody else's war? What do ya'll think you're heros...?" He laughs at the idea...

I didn't know what to say at the time, but... if he asks me again...I'd say...No. I'd say there's no way in hell...nobody asks to be a hero...it just sometimes turns out that way... And for the first time we see he's been talking to a fami man, lying motionless on a stretcher... And Eversmann, needing to make a final connection touches Smith's chest... a hero's heart... another somebody who d ask to be a hero..

(simply) I'm gonna talk to your ma and pa when I get home, okay? And we see there are other men on stretchers, other young men who left a piece of their hearts behind... And he turns and leaves...the lights forever on...the coo humming... the boys going home men...  288 128.

The cargo bay door closes on the empty cargo bay. FADE TO BLACK... LEGEND #1: During the raid over 1000 Somalis died and 19 American soldiers lost their lives. CWO Donovan Briley Staff Sgt. Daniel Busch Spec. James Ca Staff Sgt. William Cleveland Staff Sgt. Thomas Field Sgt. First Class Earl Fillmore CWO Raymond Frank Master Sgt. G Gordon Sgt. Cornell Houston Sgt. Casey Joyce Pfc. Richard Kowalewski Pfc. James Martin Master Sgt. Tim “Griz' Marti Sgt. Dominick Pilla Sgt. First Class Matt Rierson Sgt. Lo Ruiz Sgt. First Class Randy Shughart Cpl. Jamie Smith Cwo Cliff “Elvis' Wolcott

My love, you're strong and you'll do well in life. I love you and my children deeply. Today and tomorrow, with each day, grow and grow. Keep smiling and never give up, even when things get you down. So in closing my love, tonight, tuck my children in bed warmly. Tell them I love them. Then, hug them for me and, give them both a kiss good night for Daddy. Legend #2: Delta Sgts. Gary Gordon and Randy Shughart wer the first soldiers to receive the medal of honor posthumo since the Vietnam War. Michael Durant was released after 11 days of captivity. Two weeks later, President Clinton withdrew Delta Force a The Rangers from Somalia. Legend #3 Major General William F. Garrison accepted full responsibility for the outcome of the raid. On August 2, 1996, Warlord Mohamed Farrah Aidid was kille in Mogadishu. The following day, General Garrison retired
